content: reading mathematics in lean. do you know how to think correctly about the fact that i can do #check mul_comm, but can't #check ring?
mul_comm is a theorem, ring is a tactic.
There are probably under 50 tactics in common use in Lean's maths library, but there are tens of thousands of theorems.

You can get information on ring with

import Mathlib

example : 2 + 2 = 4 := by
  ring

and then you can ctrl-click on ring and jump to its definition.

The job of #check is to tell you the type of a term. In the theorem/proof universe Prop, mul_comm is actually a proof, i.e. a term, and its type is the statement of the theorem that it's a proof of.
got it, thank you! makes perfect sense now.
But you can click on pretty much any token (i.e. any meaningful atom in any Lean code) and jump to its definition.
You can't do #check ring but you can do #help tactic ring. Although for some tactics, the help text isn't that much helpful

If it's not that helpful you should try #help! tactic ring.</joke>

More seriously, if someone finds an unhelpful tactic doc then they should either complain in #mathlib4 (assuming it's a mathlib tactic) or, even better, locate the unhelpful docstring and make a PR making it better!

I really want to emphasize that if someone finds something wrong with the library documentation and it's not hard to make it better, then we would welcome a PR making it better. This is a great way to contribute to mathlib.
